titleStmt.title: A Most pleasant Comedie of Mucedorus the kings sonne of Valentia and Amadine the Kings daughter of Arragon, with the merie conceites of Mouse.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for William Iones, dwelling at Holborne conduit, at the signe of the Gunne.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. The King Rombelo Mucedorus the prince of Valensia Amadine the Kinges daughter of Arragon Segasto a Noble man Enuie Bremo a wilde man Comedy a boy an ould woman Ariena Amadines maide Collen a Counseller A messenger Mouse the Clowne Tremelio a Captaine Epilogue

div1.stage: Enter Comedie ioyfull with a garland of baies on her head.

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: WHy so? thus do I hope to please:
Music revives, and mirth is tolerable.
Comedy play thy part, and please,
Make merry them that comes to joy with thee:
Joy then good gentles, I hope to make you laugh.
Sound forth Bellonas silver tuned strings.
Time fits us well, the day and place is ours.

div1.stage: Enter Enuie, his armes naked besmearde with bloud

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Nay stay minion, there lies a block.
What all on mirth; I will interrupt your tale.
And mix your music with a tragic end.

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: What monstrous ugly hag is this,
That dares control the pleasures of our will?
Vaunt churlish cur, besmeared with gory blood,
That seemest to check the blossoms of delight,
And stifle the sound of sweet Bellonas breath.
Blush, monster blush, and post away with shame,
That seekest disturbance of a goddess deeds.

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Post hence thyself, thou counterchecking trull,
I will possess this habit spite of thee
And gain the glory of thy wished port,
I will thunder music shall appal the nymphs,
And make them shiver their clattering strings:
Flying for succour to their danes caves.
sp.stage: Sound drumes within and crie stab stab.
sp.l: Hearken, thou shalt hear a noise
Shall fill the air with a shrilling sound,
And thunder music to the gods above:
Mars shall himself breathe down
A peerless crown upon brave envy's head,
And raise his cheval with a lasting fame
In this brave music Envy takes delight,
Where I may see them wallow in their blood,
To spurn at arms and legs quite shivered off,
And hear the cries of many thousand slain,
How likest thou this my trull, this sport alone for me?

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: Vaunt bloody cur, nursed up with tigers sap,
That so dost seek to quail a woman's mind,
Comedy is mild gentle, willing for to please,
And seeks to gain the love of all estates,
Delighting in mirth, mixed all with lovely tales,
And bringeth things with treble joy to pass,
Thou bloody, Envious, disdainer of men's joy,
Whose name is fraught with bloody stratagems,
Delights in nothing but in spoil and death,
Where thou mayst trample in their lukewarm blood,
And grasp their hearts within thy cursed paws:
Yet veil thy mind, revenge thou not on me,
A silly woman begs it at thy hands,
Give me the leave to utter out my play,
Forbear this place, I humbly crave thee hence,
And mix not death amongst pleasing comedies,
That treats naught else but pleasure and delight.
If any spark of human rests in thee,
Forbear, be gon, tender the suite of me.

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Why so I will, forbearance shall be such
As treble death shall cross thee with despite,
And make thee mourn where most thou joyest,
Turning thy mirth into a deadly dole:
Whirling thy pleasures with a peal of death,
And drench thy methods in a sea of blood:
This will I do, thus shall I bear with thee
And more to vex thee with a deeper spite,
I will with threats of blood begin thy play:
Favouring thee with envy and with hate.

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: Then ugly monster do thy worst,
I will defend them in despite of thee:
And thought thou thinkst with tragic fumes
To brave my play unto my deep disgrace.
I force it not, I scorn what thou canst do
I will grace it so, thyself shall it confess:
From tragic stuff to be a pleasant comedy.

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Why then Comedy send thy actors forth
And I will cross the first steps of their tread:
Making them fear the very dart of death.

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: And I will defend them maugre all thy spite
So ugly fiend farewell, tell time shall serve,
That we may meet to parley for the best.

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Content Comedy, I will go spread my branch,
And scattered blossoms from mine envious tree.
Shall prove to monsters, spoiling of their joys.

div2.stage: Enter Segasto runing and Amadine after him, being persued with a beare

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: O fly Madam, fly or else we art but dead.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Help Segasto help, help sweet Segasto or else I die.
Alas madam, there is no way but flight,
Then haste and save yourself.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Why then I die, ah help me in distress,

div2.stage: Enter Mucedorus like a shepheard with a sworde drawne and a beares head in his hande.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Stay Lady stay, and be no more dismayed,
That cruel beast most merciless and fell,
Which have bereaved thousands of their lives,
Affrighted many with his hard pursues,
Prying from place to place to find his prey,
Prolonging thus his life by others death,
His carcass now lies headless void of breath.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: That foul deformed monster is he dead?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Assure yourself thereof, behold his head:
Which if it please you Lady to accept,
With willing heart I yield it to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Thanks worthy shepherd, thanks a thousand times
This gift assure thyself contents me more,
Than greatest bounty of a mighty prince:
Although he were the monarch of the world.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Most gracious goddess, more than mortal wight,
Your heavenly hue of right imports no less,
Most glad am I in that it was my chance,
To undertake this enterprise in hand.
Which doth so greatly glad your princely mind.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: No goddess shepherd, but a mortal wight
A mortal wight distressed as thou seest:
My father here is king of Arragon.
I Amadine his only daughter am:
And after him sole heir unto the crown.
Now where as it is my fathers will,
To marry me unto Segasto,
On whose wealth through fathers former usury
Is known to be no less than wonderful,
We both of custom oftentimes did use,
Leaving the court to walk within the fields,
For recreation especially the spring,
In that it yields great store of rare delights:
And passing further than our wonted walks,
Scarce were entered within these luckless woods,
But right before us down a steep fall hill
A monstrous ugly bear did hie him fast,
To meet us both, I faint to tell the rest,
Good shepherd, but suppose the ghastly looks,
The hideous fears, the thousand hundred woes,
Which at this instant Amadine sustained.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Yet worthy princes let thy sorrow cease,
And let this sight your former joys revive.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Believe me shepherd so it doth no less.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Long may they last unto your hearts content.
But tell me Lady what is become of him,
Segasto called, what is become of him?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I know not I, that know the powers divine.
But God grant this that sweet Segasto live.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Yet hard-hearted he in such a case,
So cowardly to save himself by flight:
And leave so brave a princess to the spoil.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Well shepherd for thy worthy valour tried,
Endangering thyself to set me free:
Unrecompenced sure thou shalt not be.
In court thy courage shall be plainly known:
Throughout the Kingdom will I spread thy name,
To thy renown and never dying fame:
And that thy courage may be better known.
Bear thou the head of this most monstrous beast
In open sight to every courtiers view
So will the king my father thee reward.
Come let us away, and guard me to the court.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: When heaps of harms do hover over head,
It is time as then, some say to look about,
And so ensuing harms to choose the least:
But hard, yea hapless is that wretch's chance,
Luckless his lot and caitiff like accursed,
At whose proceedings fortune ever frowns.
Myself I mean most subject unto thrall,
For I the more I seek to shun the worst:
The more by proof I find myself accursed:
Ere whiles assaulted with an ugly bear,
Fair Amadine in company all alone,
Forthwith by flight I thought to save myself,
Leaving my Amadine unto her shifts:
For death it was for to resist the bear.
And death no less of Amadines harms to hear.
Accursed I in lingering life thus long,
In leaving thus each minute of an hour
Doth pierce my heart with darts of thousand deaths:
If she by flight her fury do escape,
What will she think;
Will she not say; yea flatly to my face,
Accusing me of mere disloyalty,
A trusty friend is tried time of need:
But I when she in danger was of death
And needed me, and cried Segasto help:
I turned my back and quickly ran away.
Unworthy I to bear this vital breath:
But what, what needs these plaints
If Amadine do live then happy I,
She will in time forgive and so forget,
Amadine is merciful, not Iuno like.
In harmful heart to harbour hatred long.

div2.stage: Enter Mouse the Clowne running crying clubs.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Clubs, prongs, pitchforks, bills, O help, a bear, a bear, a bear.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Still bears, and nothing else but bears.
Tell me sirrah where she is;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O sir, she is run down the woods:
I see her white head and her white belly.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thou talkest of wonders, to tell me of white bears.
But sirrah didst thou ever see any such;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: No faith I never saw any such,
But I remember my fathers words,
He bad me take heed I was not caught with a white bear

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: A lamentable tale no doubt.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I tell you what sir as I was going a field to serve my fathers great horse, and carried a bottly of hay upon my head, now do you see sir, I fast hoodwinked, that I could see nothing, perceiving the bear coming, I threw my hay into the hedge and ran away.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: What from nothing;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I warrant you yes, I saw something, for there was tow load of thorns besides my bottle of hay, and that made three.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: But tell me sirrah, the bear that thou didst see,
Did she not bear a bucket on her arm;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Ha ha, ha, I never saw bear go a-milking in all
my life.
But hark you sir, I did not look so hie as her arm:
I saw nothing but her whit head, and her whit belly.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: But tell me sirrah, where dost thou dwell;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why, do you not know me.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why no, how should I know thee,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why then you know nobody, if you know not me I tell you sir I am the goodman rats son of the next parish over the hill.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Goodman rats son why what is thy name,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: why I am very near kin unto him.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I think so, but what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: My name, I have very pretty name I will tell you what my name is: my name is Mouse,

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: what plain Mouse.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Aye, plain mouse with out either welt or guard.
But do you hear sir I am but a very young mouse,
For my tail is scarce grown out yet, look you here
else.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: But I pray thee, who gave thee that name?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Faith sir I know not that, but if you would fain know, ask my fathers great horse, for he hath been half a year longer with my father than I have.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: This seems to be a merry fellow,
I care not if I take him home with me,
Mirth is a comfort to a troubled mind,
A merry man, a merry master makes.
How sayst thou sirrah, wilt thou dwell with me?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay soft sir, tow words to a bargain, pray you what occupation are you?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: No occupation, I live upon my lands.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Your lands, away, you are no master for me, why do you think that I am so mad, to go seek my living in the lands amongst the stones, briars, and bushes, and tear my holy day apparel, not I by your leave.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why, I do not mean thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why thou shalt be my man, and wait upon me at the court.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Where the King lies.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What is that same King a man or woman?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: A man as thou art.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: As I am, hark you sir pray you what kin is he to good man king of our parish the church warden?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: No kin to him, he is the King of the whole land.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: king of the land, I never see him.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: If thou wilt dwell with me, thou shalt see him every day.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: shall I go home again to be torn in pieces with bears, no not I, I will go home and put on a clean shirt, and then go drown myself.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thou shalt not need, if thou wilt dwell with me, thou shalt want nothing.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Shall I not? then here is my hand, I will dwell with you,

And hark you sir, now you have entertained me, I will tell you what I can do, I can keep my tongue from picking and stealing, and my hands from lying and slandering, I warrant you, as well as ever you had man in all your life.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Now will I to court with sorrowful heart, rounded
with doubts, if Amadine do live, then happy I: yea
happy I if Amadine do live.

div2.stage: Enter the King with a young prince prisoner, Amadine with Collen and counsellers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now brave Lords, our wars are brought to end,
Our foes the foil and we in safety rest,
It us behooves to use such clemency in peace
As valour in the war.
It is as great honour to be bountiful at home,
As to be conquerors in the field.
Therefore my Lords the more to my content,
Your liking, and your countries safeguard,
We are disposed in marriage for to give
Our daughter to Lord Segasto here,
Who shall succeed the diadem after me:
And reign hereafter as I before have done
Your sole and lawful King of Arragon:
What say you Lordings, like you of my advice?

sp.speaker: Collen
sp.p: If it please your Majesty, we do not only allow of your highness pleasure, but also vow faithfully in what we may to further it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thanks good my Lords, if long Adrostus live
Me will at full requite your courtesies.
Tremelio in recompense of thy late valour done,
Take unto thee the Catalone a prince,
Lately our prisoner taken in the wars
Be thou his keeper, his ransom shall be thine,
We will think of it when leisure shall afford:
Meanwhile do use him well, his father is a King.

sp.speaker: Tremelio
sp.l: Thanks to your Majesty, his usage shall be such,
As he thereat shall think no cause to grudge.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then march we on to court, and rest our wearied limbs
But Collen, I have a tale in secret kept for thee:
When thou shalt hear a watch word from thy king,
Think then some weighty matter is at hand
That highly shall concern our state,
Then Collen look thou be not far from me:
And for thy service thou before hast done,
Thy truth and valour proud in every point,
I shall with bounties thee enlarge therefore:
So guard us to the court.

sp.speaker: Collen
sp.l: What so my sovereign doth command me do,
With willing mind I gladly yield consent

div2.stage: Enter Segasto and the Clowne, with weapons about him

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Tell me sirrah, how do you like your weapons;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O very well, very well, they keep my sides warm.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: They keep the dogs from your shins very well
do they not;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How, keep the dogs from my shins, I would scorn but my shins should keep the dogs from them.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Well sirrah, leaving idle talk, tell me:
Dost thou know captain Tremelioes chamber;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Aye very well, it hath a door

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I think so, for so hath every chamber.
But dost thou know the man.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Aye forsooth he hath a nose on his face.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why so hath everyone

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: That is more than I know.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: But doest thou remember the captain, that was
here with the king even now, that brought the young
prince prisoner?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O very well.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Go unto him and bid him come to me,
Tell him I have a matter in secret to impart to him,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I will master, master what is his name?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why captain Tremelio.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O the meal man, I know him very well,
He brings meal every saturday: but hark you master must I bid him come to you or must you come to him

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: No sir, he must come to me.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Hark you master, how if he be not at home.
What shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why then leavest word with some of his folks.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O master, if there be nobody within,
I will leave word with his dog.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why can his dog speak;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I cannot tell, wherefore doth he keep his chamber else.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: To keep out such knaves as thou art.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay byrlady then go yourself.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: You will go sir, will ye not;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Yes marry will I, O it is come to my head,
If he be not within, I will bring his chamber to you.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: What wilt thou pluck down the Kings house?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay byrlady I will know the price of it first.
Master it is such a hard name, I have forgotten it again I pray you tell me his name,

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I tell thee captain Tremelio.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O captain treble knave, captain treble knave

sp.speaker: Tremelio
sp.l: How now sirrah, dost thou call me?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: You must come to my master captain treble knave

sp.speaker: Tremelio
sp.l: My Lord Segasto. did you send for me.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I did Tremelio, sirrah about your business.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Aye marry, what is that can you tell?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: No not well.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Marry then I can, straight to the kitchen dresser, to Iohn the cook, and get me a good piece of beef and brews, and then to the buttery hatch to Thomas the butler, for a jack of bear, and there for an hour I will so be labour myself, therefore I pray you call me not till you think I have done, I pray you good master.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Well sir away.
Tremelio this it is, thou knowest the valour of Segasto
Spread through all the kingdom of Arragon,
And such as hath found triumph and favours,
Never daunted at any time, but now a shepherd,
Admired at in court for worthiness.
And Segastoes honour laid aside.
sp.p: My will therefore is this, that thou dost find some means to work the shepherd's death, I know thy strength sufficient to perform my desire, and thy love no other wise than to revenge my injuries.

sp.speaker: Tremelio
sp.l: It is not the frowns of a shepherd that Tremelio
fears.
Therefore account it accomplished, what I take in hand

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thanks good Tremelio, and assure thyself,
What I promise that will I perform.

sp.speaker: Tremelio
sp.l: Thanks my good Lord, and in good time
See where he cometh, stand by a while.
And you shall see me put in practise your intended,
drifts.
Have at thee swain, if that I hit thee right.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Vild coward, so without cause to strike a man.
Turn coward turn, now strike and do thy worst.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Hold shepherd hold, spare him, kill him not,
Accursed villain, tell me what hast thou done.
Ah Tremelio, trusty Tremelio, I sorrow for thy death,
And since that thou living, didst prove faithful to
Segasto, so Segasto now living shall honour the dead
corpse of Tremlio with revenge.
Blood thirsty villain, born and bred to merciless
murther,
Tell me how durst thou be so bold.
As once to lay thy hands upon the least of mine.
Assure thyself, thou shalt be used according to the law.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Segasto cease, these threats are needless
Accuse not me of murther, that have done nothing
but in mine own defence.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Nay shepherd reason not with me.
I will manifest thy fact unto the King:
Whose doom will be thy death as thou deservest,
What ho, Mouse come away.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why how now, what is the matter.
I thought you would be calling before I had done.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Come help away with my friend.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why is he drunk, cannot he stand on his feet.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: No, he is not drunk, he is slain.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Slain, no byrlady he is not slain.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: He is killed I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What, do you use to kill your friends.
I will serve you no longer.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I tell thee the shepherd killed him.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O did a so, but master, I will have all his apparel
if I carry him away.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why so thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Come then I will help, mass master I think his mother song looby to him he is so heavy.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: behold the fickle state of man, always mutable,
never at one.
Sometimes we feed on fancies with the sweet of our
desires.
Sometimes again we feel the heat of extreme misery.
Now am I in favour about the court and country.
Tomorrow those favours will turn to frowns,
Today I live revenged on my foe,
Tomorrow I die, my foe revenged on me,

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: No passengers this morning, what not one.
A chance that seldom doth befall.
What not one. then lie thou there,
And rest thyself till I have further need:
Now Bremo sith thy leisure so affords.
An endless thing, who knows not Bremoes strength
Who like a king commander within these woods,
The bear, the boar, dares not abide my sight,
But hastes away to save themselves by flight:
The crystal waters in the bubbling brooks,
When I come by doth swiftly slide away,
And claps themselves in closets under banks,
Afraid to look bold Bremo in the face:
The aged oaks at Bremoes breath do bow,
And all things else are still at my command,
Else What would I?
Rent them in pieces and pluck them from the earth,
And each way else I would revenge myself,
Why who comes here with whom I dare not fight,
Who fights with me and doth not die the death; not one:
What favour shows this sturdy stick to those,
That here within these woods are combatants with
me?
Why death and nothing else but present death,
With restless rage I wander through these woods,
No creature here but feareth Bremoes force,
Man, woman, child, beast and bird,
And everything that doth approach my sight,
Are forced to fall if Bremo once but frown,
Come cudgel come, my partner in my spoils,
For here I see this day it will not be,
But when it falls that I encounter any,
One pat sufficed for to work my will.
What comes not one? then let us begone,
A time will serve when we shall better speed.

div2.stage: Enter the King, Segasto, the Shepheard and the Clowne with others.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shepherd, thou hast heard thine accusers,
Murther is laid to thy charge,
What canst thou say, thou hast deserved death;

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Dread sovereign, I must needs confess,
I slew this captain in mine own defence,
Not of any malice but by chance,
But mine accuser hath a further meaning.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: words will not here prevail,
I seek for justice, and justice craves his death.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shepherd thine own confession hath condemned
thee.
Sirrah take him away, and do him to execution straight.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: So he shall I warrant him, but do you hear master King, he is kin to a monkey, his neck is bigger than is head.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Come sirrah away with him, and hang him about the middle.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Yes forsooth I warrant you, come on sir, a so like a sheep biter he looks.

div2.stage: Enter Amadine and a boie with a beares head

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Dread sovereign and well-beloved sire.
On bended knees I crave the life of this condemned
shepherd, which heretofore preserved the life of thy
sometime distressed daughter.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: preserved the life of my sometime distressed daughter
How can that be; I never knew the time
Wherein thou wast distressed, I never knew the day
But that I have maintained thy state,
As best beseemed the daughter of a king
I never saw the shepherd until now,
How comes it then that he preserved thy life?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Once walking with Segasto in the woods,
Further than our accustomed manner was,
Right before us down a steep fall hill,
A monstrous ugly bear doth hie him fast
To meet us both, now whether this be true,
I refer it to the credit of Segasto.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Most true and like your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: The bear being eager to obtain his prey;
Made forward to us with an open mouth,
As if he meant to swallow us both at once,
The sight whereof did make us both to dread,
But specially your daughter Amadine,
Who for I saw no succour incident
But in Segastoes valour, I grew desperate,
And he most coward-like began to fly.
Left me distressed to be devoured of him,
How say you Segasto is it not true?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His silence verifies it to be true, what then;

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Then I amazed distressed all alone,
Did hie me fast to scape that ugly bear,
But all in vain, for why he reached after me,
And hardly I did oft escape his paws,
Till at the length this shepherd came,
And brought to me his head.
Come hither boy, lo here it is, which I present unto
your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The slaughter of this bear deserves great fame.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: The slaughter of a man deserves great blame.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Indeed occasion oftentimes so falls out.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Tremelio in the wars. O King preserved thee,

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: The shepherd in the woods o king preserved me.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Tremelio fought when many men did yield.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: So would the shepherd had he been in field

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: So would my master, had he not run away.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Tremelioes force saved thousands from the foe.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: The shepherd's force have saved thousand,
more.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Aye shipsticks, nothing else.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Segasto cease to accuse the shepherd,
His worthiness deserves a recompense,
All we are bound to do the shepherd good:
Shepherd, whereas it was my sentence, thou shouldst die,
So shall my sentence stand, for thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thanks to your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But soft Segasto, not for this offence,
Long mayst thou live, and when the sisters shall decree
To cut in twain the twisted thread of life,
Then let him die, for this I set thee free,
And for thy valour I will honour thee.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Thanks to your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come daughter let us now depart, to honour
the worthy valour of the shepherd with our rewards.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O master hear you, you have made a fresh hand now you would be slow you, why what will you do now? you have lost me a good occupation by the means, Faith master now I cannot hang the shepherd, I pray you let me take the pains to hang you, it is but half an hour's exercise.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: You are still in your knavery, but sith I cannot have his life I will procure his banishment for ever. Come on sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Yes forsooth I come laugh at him I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: From Amadine and from her fathers court,
With gold and silver and with rich rewards,
Flowing from the banks of golden treasuries,
More may I boast and say but I,
Was never shepherd in such dignity,

div2.stage: Enter the messengers and the clowne.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: All hail worthy shepherd.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: All rain lousy shepherd.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Welcome my friends, from whence come you;

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The King and Amadine greets thee well,
And after greetings done, bids thee depart the court,
shepherd begone.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Shepherd take law legs, fly away shepherd

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Whose words are these? came these from
Amadine?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Aye from Amadine.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Aye from Amladine.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Ah luckless fortune worse than Phaetons tale,
My former bliss is now become my bale.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What wilt thou poison thyself?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: My former heaven is now become my hell.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: The worst ale house that I ever came in, in all my life.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: What shall I do.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Even go hang thyself half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Can Amadine so churlishly command.
To banish the shepherd from her Fathers court?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: What should shepherds do in the court.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What should shepherdess do amongst us, have we not Lords enough on us in the court?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Why shepherds are men, and kings are no more.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Shepherds are men and masters over their flock

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: That is a lie who pays them their wages then?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Well you are always interrupting of me,
But you are best look to him lest you hang for him when he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.l: And you shall hang for company,
For leaving me alone.
Shepherd stand forth and hear thy sentence,
Shepherd begone within three days in pain of,
My displeasure, shepherd begone, shepherd begone, begone, begone, begone, shepherd, shepherd, shepherd

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: And must I go, and must I needs depart?
Ye goodly groves partakers of my songs
In time before when fortune did not frown,
Pour forth your plaints and wail a while with me
And thou bright sun my comfort in the cold,
Hide, hide thy face and leave me comfortless,
Ye wholesome herbs, and sweet smelling savours,
Ye each thing else prolonging life of man,
Change, change your wonted course,
That I wanting your aid, in woeful sort may die,

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Arinea if anybody ask for me,
Make some excuse till I return.

sp.speaker: Ariena
sp.l: What if Segasto call.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Do thou the like to him, I mean not to stay long

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: This voice so sweet my pining spirits revives

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Shepherd, well met tell me how thou doest.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I linger life yet wish for speedy death.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Shepherd, although thy banishment already be
decreed and all against thy will, yet Amadine.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Ah Amadine, to hear of banishment is death,
Aye double death to me, but since I must depart, one thing
I crave.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Say on with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: That in absence either far or near.
You honour me as servant with your name.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Not so.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I honour thee as sovereign with my heart.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: A shepherd and a sovereign nothing like.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Yet like enough where there is no dislike.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Yet great dislike or else no banishment.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Shepherd, it is only Segasto that procures thy
banishment.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Unworthy wights are most in jealousy.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Would God they would free thee from banishment,
or likewise banish me.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Amen say I, to have your company.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Well shepherd, sith thou sufferest this for my
sake, with thee in exile also let me live.
On this condition shepherd thou canst love.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: No longer love no longer let me live.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Of late I loved one indeed, now love I none but
only thee.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Thanks worthy princes I born likewise,
Yet smother up the blast,
I dare not promise what I may perform,

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Well shepherd, hark what I shall say,
I will return unto my Fathers court.
Therefore to provide me of such necessaries,
As for our journey I shall think most fit,
This being done I will return to thee,
Do thou therefore appoint the place where we may
meet.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Down in the valley where I slew the bear,
And there doth grow a fair broad branched beach,
That over-shades a well, so who comes first
Let them abide the happy meeting of us both.
How like you this?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I like it very well.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Now if you please you may appoint the time,

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Full three hours hence God willing, I will
return.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: The thanks that paris gave the grecian queen
the like doth Mucedorns yield.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Then Mucedorus for three hours farewell.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Your departure lady breeds a privy pain.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: It is well Segasto that thou hast thy will,
Should such a shepherd, such a simple swain
As he, eclipse thy credit famous through the court.
No ply Segasto ply; let it not in Arragon be said,
A shepherd hath Segatoes honour won.

div2.stage: Enter Mouse the clowne calling his maister

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What ho master will you come away;

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Will you come hither I pray you, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why, is it not past eleven o'clock.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: How then sir.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I pray you come away to dinner:

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I pray you come hither.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Here is such a do with you, will you never come.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I pray you sir what news of the message I sent you about,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I tell you all the messes be on the table already,
There wants not so much as a mess of mustard half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Come sir, your mind is all upon your belly.
You have forgotten what I did bid you do,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Faith I know nothing, but you bad me go to breakfast.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Was that all;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Faith I have forgotten it, the very scent of the meat made me hath forget it quite.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: You have forgotten the arrant I bid you do.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What arrant, an arrant knave, or arrant whore;

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why thou knave, did I not bid thee banish the
shepherd.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O the shepherds bastard.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I tell thee the shepherd's banishment.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I tell you the shepherds bastard shall be well kept I will look to it myself else, but I pray you come away to dinner.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Then you will not tell me whether you have banished him or no.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why I cannot say banishment and you would give me a thousand pounds to say so,

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why you whoreson slave, have you forgotten, that
I sent you, and another to drive away the shepherd.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What an ass are you. here is a stir in deed here is message, arrant, banishment, and I cannot tell what.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I pray you sir, shall I know whether you have drove him away.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Faith I think I have, if you will not believe me ask my staff.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why can thy staff tell.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why he was with me too.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Then happy I that have obtained my will.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: And happier I, if you would go to dinner.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Come sirrah, follow me.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I warrant you I will not loose an inch of you now you are going to dinner, I promise you I thought seven year before I could get him away

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: God grant my long delay procures no harm
Nor this my tarring frustrate my pretence,
My Mucedorus surely stays for me,
And thinks me over long, at length I come
My present promise to perform:
Ah what a thing is firm unfeigned love,
What is it which true love dares not tempt
My father he may make but I must match,
Segasto loves but Amadine must like,
Where likes her best compulsion is a thrall,
No, no, the hearty choice is all in all,
The shepherds virtue Amadine esteems.
But what methinks my shepherd is not come?
I muse at that, the hour is sure at hand,
Well here I will rest till Mucedorus come.

div2.stage: Enter Bremo looking about, hastily taketh hould of her.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: A happy prey, now Bremo feed on flesh,
Dainties Bremo dainties thy hungry paunch to fill,
Now glut thy greedy guts with luke warm blood,
Come fight with me, I long to see thee dead.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: How can she fight that weapons cannot wield?

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: What canst not fight? then lie thou down and die.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: What must I die?

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: What needs these words. I thirst to suck thy blood

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Yet pity me and let me live a while.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: No pity I, I will feed upon thy flesh,
I will tear thy body piecemeal joint from joint.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah now I want my shepherds company.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: I will crush thy bones betwixt tow oaken trees.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Haste shepherd haste or else thou comest too late.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: I will suck the sweetness from thy marrow bones.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah spare ah spare to shed my guiltless blood

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: With this my bat will I beat out thy brains
Down, down I say, prostrate thyself upon the ground

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Then Mucedorus farewell. my hoped joys farewell.
Yea farewell life, and welcome present death,
To thee O God I yield my dying ghost.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Now Bremo play thy part,
How now what sudden chance is this.
My limbs do tremble and my sinews shake
My unweakened arms have lost their former force:
Ah Bremo, Bremo, what a foil hast thou,
That yet at no time ever wast afraid
To dare the greatest gods to fight with thee,
And now want strength for one down driving blow
Ah how my courage fails when I should strike,
Some new come spirit abiding in my breast,
Shall I spare her Bremo, spare her, do not kill,
Saith spare her which never spared any?
To it Bremo to it, say again.
I cannot wield my weapons in my hand,
Methinks I should not strike so fair a one,
I think her beauty hath bewitched my force
Or else with in me altered natures course,
aye woman, wilt thou live in woods with me;

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Fain would I live, yet loath to live in woods,

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Thou shalt not choose, it shall be as I say and therefore
follow me.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: It was my will an hour ago and more,
As was my promise for to make return,
But other business hindered my pretence.
It is a world to see when man appoints,
And purposely one certain thing decrees
How many things may hinder his intent.
What once would wish the same is farthest off:
But yet the appointed time cannot be past,
Nor hath her presence yet prevented we,
Well here I will stay, and expect her coming.

div2.stage: They crie within, hould him, staie him, holde

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Some one or other is pursued no doubt
Perhaps some search for me, it is good to doubt the
worst, therefore I will begone.

div2.stage: Crie within hold him, hold him, Enter Mouse the Clowne with a pot.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Hold him, hold him hold him, here is a stir in deed
Here came hue after the crier, and I was set close
At mother Nips house, and there I called for three
Pots of ale, as it is the manner of us courtiers, now sirrah,
I had taken the maiden head of tow of them.

Now as I was lifting up the third to my mouth, there came hold him, hold him, now I could not tell whom to catch hold on, but I am sure I caught one perchance he may be in this pot, well I will see, mass I cannot see him yet, well I will look a little

further, mass he is a little slave if he be here, why here is nobody, all this goes well yet: but if the old trot should come for her pot, Aye marry there is the matter but I care not, I will face her out, and call her old rusty dusty musty
fusty crusty firebrand, and worse than all that, and so face her out of her pot: but soft here she comes.

sp.speaker: ould woman
sp.p: Come on you gnaw wheres my pot you knave?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Go look your pot, come not to me for your pot it were good for you.

sp.speaker: ould woman
sp.p: Thou liest thou knave thou hast my pot.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: You lie if you say it, I your pot, I know what I will say

sp.speaker: ould woman
sp.p: Why what wilt thou say.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: But say I have him and thou darest,

sp.speaker: ould woman
sp.p: Why thou knave. thou hast not only my pot but my drink unpaid for.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: You lie like an old I will not say whore.

sp.speaker: ould woman
sp.p: dost thou call me whore, I will cap thee my for pot.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Cap me if thou darest, search me whether I have it or no.

div2.stage: Shee searcheth him, and he drinketh ouer her head and casts downe the pot, she stumbleth at it, then they fal together by the eares, she takes her pot and goes out.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: How now sirrah, what is the matter;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O flies master flies.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Flies where are they?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O here master, all about your face.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why thou liest I think thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why master, I have killed a dungcart full at the least

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Go to sirrah, leaving this idle talk give ear to me.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How, give you one of my ears? not if you were ten masters.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why sir I bid you give ear to my words,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I tell you I will no be made a curtal for no man's pleasure

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I tell thee attend what I say go thy ways straight and rear the whole town.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How rear the town even go yourself, it is more than I can do, why do you think I can rear a town, that can scarce rear a pot of ale to my head? I should rear a town should I not;

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Go to the constable and make a privy search, for the shepherd is run away with the Kings daughter.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How? is the shepherd run away with the kings daughter. or is the kings daughter run away with the shepherd.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I cannot tell, but they are both gon together

sp.speaker: Mouse
Segasto
sp.l: why dost thou think they will be there;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Well then search everywhere. leave no place
unsearched for them.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O now am I in office, now will I to that old firebrand's house and will not leave one place unsearched,
nay I will to her ale stand and drink as long as I can stand, and when I have done I will let out all the rest,
to see if he be not hid in the barrel, if I find him not there, I will to the cupboard, I will not leave one corner of her house unsearched, ye faith ye old crust I will be with you now.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Now Mucedorus whither wilt thou go,
Home to thy father to thy native soil,
Or try some long abode within these woods;
Well I will hence depart and hie me home,
What hie me home said I? that may not be.
In Amadine rests my felicity
Then Mucedorus do as thou didst decree,
Attire thee hermit like, within these groves,
Walk often to the beach and view the well.
Make settles there and seat thyself thereon,
And when thou feelest thyself to be a thirst,
Then drink a hearty draught to Amadine,
No doubt she thinks on thee,
And will one day come pledge thee at this well.
Come habit thou art fit for me,
No shepherd now, a hermit I must be:
Methinks this fits me very well,
Now must I learn to bear a walking staff,
And exercise some gravity withal.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Here is through the woods, and through the woods, to look out a shepherd and a stray kings daughter, but
soft who have we here, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I am an hermit.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: An emmet, I never saw such big emmet in all my life before.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I tell you sir I am an hermit, one that leads a solitary
life within these woods.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O I know thee now, thou art her that eats up all the hips and haws, we could not have one piece of fat bacon for thee all this year.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Thou dost mistake me, but I pray thee tell me
what dost thou seek in these woods?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What do I seek, for a stray Kings daughter run away with a shepherd:

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: A stray Kings daughter run away with a shepherd.
Wherefore canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Yes that I can, it is this, my master and Amadins walking one day abroad,
nearer to these woods than they were used, about what I can not tell, but toward them
comes running a great bear, now my master he played the man and run away, and Amadine crying
after him: now sir comes me a shepherd and strikes off the bears
head, now whether the bear where dead before or no I cannot tell for bring twenty bears
before me and bind their hands and feet and I will kill them all: now ever
since Amadine hath been in love with the shepherd, and for good will she is even
run away with the shepherd.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: What manner of man was he, canst describe him unto me;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Scribe him aye I warrant you that I can, he was a little,
low, broad, tall, narrow, big well favoured fellow, a jerkin of whit cloth,
and buttons of the same cloth

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.p: Thou describest him well, but if I chance to see any
such, pray you where shall I find you, or what is your name

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: My name is called master mouse,

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: O master mouse, I pray you what office might
you bear in the court?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Marry sir I am a rusher of the stable.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: O usher of the table-

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay I say rusher and I will prove mine office good,
for look sir when any comes from under the sea or so,
and a dog chance to blow his nose backward, then with a whip I give him
the good time of the day, and straw rushes presently, therefore I am a rusher, a hie office I promise ye.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: But where shall I find you in the Court?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why where it is best being, either in the kitchen
a-eating or in the buttery drinking: but if you come
I will provide for thee a piece of beef and brews knuckle
deep in fat, pray you take pains remember master mouse.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Aye sir, I warrant I will not forget you.
Ah Amadine, what should become of thee.
whither shouldst thou go so long unknown.
with watch and ward each passage is beset,
So that she cannot long escape unknown:
Doubtless she hath lost herself within these woods
And wandering to and fro she seeks the well,
Which yet she cannot find, therefore will I seek hers out,

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Amadine, how like you Bremo and his woods?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: As like the woods of Bremoes cruelty,
Though I were dumb and could not answer him,
The beasts themselves would with relenting tears
Bewail thy savage and unhumane deeds.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: My love, why dost thou murmur to thyself?
Speak louder, for thy Bremo hears thee not.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: My Bremo, no the shepherd is my love.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Have I not saved thee from sudden death,
Giving thee leave to live that thou mightst love?
And dost thou whet me on to cruelty;
Come kiss me sweet for all my favours past.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I may not Bremo and therefore pardon me.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: See how she flings away from me;
I will follow and give a rend to her,
Deny my love, ah worm of beauty
I will chastise thee: come, come, prepare thy head upon the block

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: O spare me Bremo love should limit life,
Not to be made a murderer of himself
If thou wilt glut thy loving heart with blood,
Encounter with the lion or the bear,
And alike wolf prey not upon a lamb.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Why then dost thou repine at me?
If thou wilt love me thou shalt be my queen,
I will crown thee with a complete made of Ivory,
And make the rose and lily wait on thee,
I will rend the burly branches from the oak,
To shadow thee from burning sun.
The trees shall spread themselves where thou dost go,
And as they spread, I will trace along with thee,

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Thou shalt be fed with quails and partridges
With black birds, larks, thrushes and nightingales.
Thy drink shall be goats milk and crystal water,
Distilled from the fountains and the clearest springs.
And all the dainties that the woods afford.
I will freely give thee to obtain thy love.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: The day I will spend to recreate my love,
With all the pleasures that I can devise
And in the night I will be thy bedfellow,
And lovingly embrace thee in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: One may, so may not you.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: The satyrs and the woodnymphs shall attend on thee
And lull thee asleep with musics sound,
And in the morning when thou dost awake
The lark shall sing good morn to my queen,
And whilst he singes I will kiss my Amadine.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: You may, for who but you.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: When thou art up, the wood lanes shall be strawed
With violets, cowslips and sweet marigolds.
For thee to trample and to trace upon,
And I will teach thee how to kill the deer,
To chase the hart and how to rouse the roe,
If thou wilt live to love and honour me.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: You may, for who but you?

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Welcomed sir, an hour ago I looked for such a guest
Be merry wench, we will have a frolic feast,
Here is flesh enough for to suffice us both,
Stay sirrah, wilt thou fight or dost thou yield to die?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I want a weapon, how can I fight?

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Thou wants a weapon, why then thou yieldest to
die.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I say not so, I do not yield to die.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Thou shalt not choose, I long to see thee dead

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Yet spare him Bremo spare him

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Away, I say, I will not spare him.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Yet give me leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Thou shalt not speak.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Yet give him leave to speak for my sake.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Speak on, but be not over long.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: In time of yore when men like brutish beasts.
Did lead their lives in loathsome cells and woods
And wholly gave themselves to witless will,
A rude unruly rout, then man to man became
A present prey, then might prevailed,
The weakest went to walls,
Right was unknown, for wrong was all in all.
As men thus lived in his great outrage,
Behold one Orpheus came as poets tell,
And them from rudeness unto reason brought,
Who led by reason's son some forsook the woods,
Instead of caves they built them castles strong,
Cities and towns were founded by them then,
Glad were they, they found such ease,
And in the end they grew to perfect amity
Weighing their former wickedness,
They termed the time wherein they lived then
A golden age, a goodly golden age.
Now Bremo, for so I hear thee called.
If men which lived before as thou dost now,
Wildly in wood, addicted all to spoil,
Returned were by worthy Orpheus means,
Let me like Orpheus cause thee to return
From murder, bloodshed and like cruelty,
What should we fight before we have a cause
No, let us live and love together faithfully.
I will fight for thee.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Fight for me or die, or fight or else thou diest.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: hold Bremo hold,

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Away I say, thou troublest me,

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: You promised me to make me your queen.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: I did, I mean no less.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: You promised that I should have my will,

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: I did I mean no less.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Then save this hermits life, for he may save us both:

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: At thy request I will spare him, but never any after him
Say hermit what canst thou do?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I will wait on thee, sometime upon the queen,
such service shalt thou shortly have as Bremo never
had.

div2.stage: Enter Segasto, the Clowne and Rumbelo.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Come sirs what shall I never have you find out
Amadine and the shepherd

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: And I have been through the woods, and through the woods, and could see nothing but an emmet.

sp.speaker: Rombelo
sp.p: Why I see thousand emmets, thou meanest a little one,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay that emmet that I saw was bigger than thou art

sp.speaker: Rombelo
sp.p: Bigger than I what a fool have you to your man,
I pray you master turn him away?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: But dost thou hear, was he not a man.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: think he was, for he said he did lead a saltseller life about the woods.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thou wouldst say a solitary life about the woods

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I think it was so indeed.

sp.speaker: Rombelo
sp.p: I thought what a fool thou art.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Thou art a wise man, why he did nothing but sleep since he went

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: But tell me Mouse, how did he go;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: In a whit gown and a whit hat on his head, and a staff in his hand.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: I thought so, it was a hermit that walked a solitary
life in the woods.
Well, get you to dinner, and after never leave
seeking till you bring some news of them, or I will hang
you both.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How now Rombelo, what shall we do now;

sp.speaker: Rombelo
sp.p: Faith I will home to dinner, and afterwards to sleep.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why then thou wilt be hanged.

sp.speaker: Rombelo
sp.p: Faith I care not, for I know I shall never find them
well I will once more abroad, and if I cannot find them, I will
never come home again.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I tell thee what Rombelo, thou shalt go in at one end of the wood
and I at the other, and we will meet both together at the midst.

sp.speaker: Rombelo
sp.p: Content, let us away to dinner.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Unknown to any here within these woods
With bloody Bremo do I lead my life,
The monster he doth murther all he meets,
He spareth none and none doth him escape,
Who would continue, who but only I
In such a cruel cutthroat's company.
Yet Amadine is there how can I choose:
Ah silly soul how often times she sits
And sighs, and calls come shepherd come,
Sweet Mucedorus, come and set me free,
When Mucedorus peasant stands hereby:
But here she comes, what news fair Lady as you
walk these woods.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah hermit, none but bad and such as thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: How do you like your Bremo and his woods;

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Not my Bremo nor his Bremo woods;

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: And why, not yours, methinks he loves you well

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I like him not, his love to me is nothing wroth

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Lady, in this methinks you offer wrong,
To hate the man that ever loves you best.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah hermit, I take no pleasure in his love.
Neither yet doth Bremo like me best.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: pardon my boldness fair lady, sith we both
May safely talk now out of Bremos sight,
Unfold to me if so you please, the full discourse
How, when and why you came into these woods,
And fell into this bloody butcher's hands.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Hermit I will, of late a worthy shepherd I did
you love.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: A shepherd lady, sure a man unfit to match with

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Hermit this is true, and when we had.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Stay there, the wild men comes
Refer the rest until another time.
What secret tale is this, what whispering have we here;
Villain I charge thee tell thy tale again,

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Aye needs I must, lo here it is again,
When as we both had lost the sight of thee
It grieved us both, but specially thy queen,
Who in thy absence ever fears the worst,
Lest some mischance befall your royal grace.
Shall my sweet Bremo wander through the woods.
Toil to and fro for to redress my want,
Hazard his life and all to cherish me,
I like not this quoth she
And thereupon craved to know of me
If I could teach her handle weapons well.
My answer was I had small skill therein,
But gladmost mighty king to learn of thee.
And this was all.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Was it so, none can dislike of this.
I will teach you both to fight, but first my queen begin,
Here take this weapon, see how thou canst use it.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: This is too big, I cannot wield it in my arm.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Is it so, we will have a knotty crabtree staff for thee:
But sirrah tell me, what sayst thou.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: With all my heart I willing am to learn.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: Then take my staff and see how canst wield it.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: First teach me how to hold it in my hand.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.p: Thou holdest it well, look how he doth thou mayst the sooner learn.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Next tell me how and when it is best to strike.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.p: It is best to strike when time doth serve, it is best to loose no time.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Then now or never is my time to strike.

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: And when thou strikest, be sure thou hit the head

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: The head;

sp.speaker: Bremo
sp.l: The very head.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Then have at thine, so lie there and die,
A death no doubt according to desert.
Or else a worse as thou deservest a worse.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: It glads my heart this tyrants death to see.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Now lady it remains in you to end the tale you
lately had begun, being interrupted by this wicked
wight.
You said you loved a shepherd.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Aye so I do, and none but only him.
And will do still as long as life shall last

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: But tell me lady, sith I set you free,
What course of life do you intend to take?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I will disguised wander through the world
Till I have found him out,

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: How if you find your shepherd in these woods

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah none so happy then as Amadine.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: In tract of time a man may alter much,
Say Lady do you know your shepherd well?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: My Mucedorus hath he set me free?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: he hath set thee free.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: And lived so long unknown to Amadine.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Aye that is a question where of you may not
be resolved,
You know that I am banished from the court,
I know likewise each passage is beset,
So that we cannot long escape unknown,
Therefore my will is this, that we return
Right through the thickets to the wild man's cave:
And there a while live on his provision,
Until the search and narrow watch be past.
This is my counsel, and I think it best.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: I think the very same.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Come let us begone.

div2.stage: The Clowne searches and fals ouer the wild man and so carry him away.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay soft sir are you here. a bots on you,
I was like to be hanged for not finding you,
We would borrow a certain stray kings daughter of you, a wench, a wench
sir we would have.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: A wench of me I will make the eat my sword.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O Lord, nay and you are so lusty I will call a cooling card for you, ho master, master come away quickly.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: What is the matter;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Look master, Amadine and the shepherd, o brave

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: What minion, have I found you out;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Nay that is a lie, I found her out myself.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thou gadding housewife, what cause hadst thou to
gad abroad,
When as thou knowest our wedding day so nigh?

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Not so Segasto, no such thing in hand,
show your assurance, then I will answer you.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Thy fathers promise my assurance is.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: But what he promised he hath not performed.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: It rests in thee for to perform the same:

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: And why;

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: So is my will, and therefore even so.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Master with a nonny, nonny no.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: A wicked villain art thou here?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: What needs these words we way them not?

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: We way them not proud shepherd, I scorn thy
company.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: We will not have a corner of thy company.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I scorn not thee, nor yet the least of thine.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: That is a lie, he would have killed me with his pugs nondo.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: This stoutness Amadine contents me not.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Then seek another that may you better please

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Well Amadine, it only rests in thee
Without delay to make thy choice of three,
There stands Segasto, here a shepherd stands,
There stands the third, now make thy choice,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: A Lord at the least I am.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: My choice is made, for I will none but
thee.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: A worthy mate no doubt for such a wife.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: And Amadine, why wilt thou none but me?
I cannot keep thee as thy father did,
I have no lands for to maintain thy state.
Moreover if thou mean to be my wife,
Commonly this must be thy use,
To bed at midnight, up at four,
Drudge all day and trudge from place to place,
Whereby our daily victual for to win:
And last of all which is the worst of all,
No princess then but plain a shepherd's wife.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Then god give you god morrow goody shepherd

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: It shall not need if Amadine do live,
Thou shalt be crowned king of Arragon,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O master laugh, when he is King then I will be a queen.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Then know that which never before was known
I am no shepherd, no Arragonian I,
But born of Royal blood, my fathers of Valentia
King, my mother queen, who for thy secret sake
Took this hard task in hand.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah how I joy my fortune is so good,

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Well now I see, Segasto shall not speed
But Mucedorus, I as much do joy
To see thee here within our Court of Arragon,
As if a kingdom had befallen me this time,
I with my heart surrender it to thee.
And look what right to Amadine I have.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: What barnes door and born where my father
Was constable. abots on thee, how dost thee.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Thanks Segasto, but yet you leveled at the crown.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Master bear this and bear all.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Why so sir.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: He sees sees you take a goose by the crown.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Go to sir, away, post you to the king,
Whose heart is fraught with careful doubts,
Glad him up and tell him these good news,
And we will follow as fast as we may.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: I go master, I run master.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Break heart and end my paled woes,
My amadine the comfort of my life,
How can I joy except she were in sight.
Her absence breeds sorrow to my soul
And with a thunder breaks my heart in twain.

sp.speaker: Collen
sp.l: Forbear those passions gentle King,
And you shall see it will turn unto the best,
And bring your soul to quiet and to joy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Such joy as death, I do assure me that,
And naught but death, unless of her I hear,
And that with speed, I cannot sigh thus long
But what a tumult do I hear within.

div2.stage: The crie within ioie and happinesse.

sp.speaker: Collen
sp.l: I hear a noise of over-passing joy
Within the court, my Lord be of good comfort.
And here comes one in haste,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: A King, a King, a King.

sp.speaker: Collen
sp.l: Why how now sirrah, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O it is news for a king it is worth money.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why sirrah, thou shalt have silver and gold if it be
good.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O it is good, it is good, Amadine.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O what of her, tell me? and I will make thee a knight

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: How a spirit? no byrlady, I will not be a spirit,
Masters get ye away, if I be a spirit, I shall be so lean
I shall make you all afraid.

sp.speaker: Collen
sp.l: Thou sot, the King means to make thee a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why I shall want apparel.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou shalt want for nothing.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Then stand away, trick up thyself, here they come.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: My gracious father pardon thy disloyal daughter

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What do mine eyes be hold my daughter Amadine
Rise up dear daughter and let these my embracing arms
Show some token of thy father joy,
Which ever since thy departure hath languished in
sorrow:

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Dear father, never were your sorrows
Greater than my griefs,
Never you so desolate as I comfortless,
Yet nevertheless acknowledging myself
To be the cause of both, on bended knees
I humbly crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I will pardon thee dear daughter. but as for him.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: Ah father what of him,

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Assure as I am a king, and wear the crown,
I will revenge on that accursed wretch.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Yet worthy prince work not thy will in wrath
show favour.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Aye, such favour as thou deservest.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: I do deserve the daughter of a king.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O impudent, a shepherd and so insolent.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: No shepherd I, but a worthy prince.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: In far conceit, not princely born.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Yes princely born my father is a king.
My mother Queen, and of Valentia both.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What Mucedorns, welcome to our court,
What cause hadst thou to come to me disguised?

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: No cause to fear, I caused no offence,
But this desiring thy daughters vertues for to see
Disguised myself from out my fathers court,
Unknown to any in secret I did rest,
And passed many troubles near to death,
So hath your daughter my partaker been,
As you shall know hereafter more at large,
Desiring you, you will give her to me,
Even as mine own and sovereign of my life
Then shall I think my travels are well spent.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: With all my heart: but this.
Segasto claims my promise made before,
That he should have her as his only wife,
Before my counsel when we came from war
Segasto, may I crave thee let it pass.
And give Amadine as wife to Mucedorus;

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: With all my heart, were it far a greater thing,
And what I may to furnish up their rites,
With pleasing sports and pastimes you shall see.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thanks good Segasto, I will think of this.

sp.speaker: Mucedorus
sp.l: Thanks good my Lord, and while I live
Account of me in what I can or may.

sp.speaker: Amadine
sp.l: And good Segasto these great courtesies
Shall not be forgot.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Why hark you master, bones what have you done?
What given away the wench you made me take such pains for,
you are wise indeed, mass if I had known of that I would have had her
myself. faith master now we may go to breakfast with a woodcock pie.

sp.speaker: Segasto
sp.l: Go sir you were best leave this knavery.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come on my Lords, let us now to court
Where we may finish up the joyfullest day
That ever happed to a distressed King,
With mirth and joy and great solemnity,
We will finish up these hymens rights most pleasant lie,

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: Ho Lords at the first, I am one too, but hear master King by your leave a cast,
now you have done with them, I pray you begin with me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why what wouldst thou have;

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: O you forgot, now, a little apparel to makes
handsome what should Lords go so beggarly as I do?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What I did promise thee, I will perform, attend
on me, come let us depart.
We will wait on you with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Mouse
sp.p: And with a piece of my liver too.

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: How now Envy, what blushest thou already,
Peep forth, hide not thy head with shame,
But with a courage praise a woman's deeds,
Thy threats were vain, thou couldst do me no hurt
Although thou seemest to cross me with despite,
I overwhelmed, and turned upside down thy block
And made thyself to stumble at the same.

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Though stumbled yet not overthrown,
Thou canst not draw my heart to mildness,
Yet must I needs confess thou hast don well,
And played thy part with mirth and pleasant glee:
Say all this, yet canst thou not conquer me,
Although this time thou hast got yet not the conquest neither.
A double revenge another time I will have:

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: Then caitiff cursed, stoop upon thy knee,
Yield to a woman, though not to me,
And pray we both together with our hearts,
That she thrice Nestors years may with us rest,
And from her foes high God defend her still.
That they against her may never work their will.

sp.speaker: Enuie
sp.l: Envy were he never so stout
Would beck and bow unto her majesty,
Indeed Comedy thou hast overrun me now.
And forced me stoop unto a woman's sway.
God grant her grace amongst us long may reign,
And those that would not have it so,
Would that by envy soon their hearts they might forgo.

sp.speaker: Comedy
sp.l: The Counsel, Noble, and this Realm,
Lord guide it still with thy most holy hand,
The Commons and the subjects grant them grace,
Their prince to serve, her to obey, and treason to deface:
Long may she reign, in joy and great felicity,
Each Christian heart do say amen with me,
